<<<<brief hospital course>>>>
Brief Hospital Course:
87 year old Female with history of Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) on 5 liters of oxygen at baseline, tracheobronchomalacia status post stent, presents with acute dyspnea over several days, no status post intubation for hypercarbic respiratory failure.

# Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Presents with dyspnea, but no clear cough or fevers. Per report, patient felt like this with prior COPD exacerbations. Leukocytosis supports possible pneumonia, but history and Chest X-ray (CXR) not entirely consistent with this. Electrocardiogram (EKG) with signs of demand, but Rule Out Myocardial Infarction (ROMI) negative. Sputum gram stain unremarkable, but respiratory viral culture grew parainfluenza type 3 on [Date]. Patient was initially managed on solumedrol 60 mg intravenous (IV) every 8 hours, and was eventually tapered. With no evidence of pneumonia on CXR and sputum gram stain, antibiotics were stopped on [Date]. Beta-agonists and anticholinergics were continued around the clock. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) with normal ejection fraction (EF), increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) (>18mmHg), Normal Right Ventricle (RV), and moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. On [Date], bronchoscopy revealed collapsible, unremarkable airways. Patient had difficulty weaning from the ventilator, and would become intermittently hypertensive to Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) in the 200s and tachypneic to the 50s. Patient was extubated on [Date] after passing Spontaneous Breathing Trial (SBT) 0/5, but required re-intubation 30 minutes later for worsening secretions, lack of gag reflex, and tachypnea to the 50s. Of note, on [Date], the patient was found to have Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) growing in sputum samples. Although it was felt that this likely represented colonization as opposed to true infection, the patient was started on a course of vancomycin (which was stopped after 5 days). After multiple discussions between the patient's family and the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) team, the patient's Primary Care Physician (PCP), [Name] the palliative care service, the patient's family ultimately decided that she would not want a tracheostomy. On [Date], extubation was pursued again and was successful. After extubation, her respiratory status improved and she was ultimately called out to the medical floor. On the floor she was progressively weaned to 2 liters of nasal cannula (LNC) with nebulizers (better than her baseline 5L at home). Because of clinical exams revealing mild volume overload, she was intermittently diuresed. She also experienced intermittent shortness of breath with tachypnea but this was thought to be the result of attacks of anxiety with tachypnea. After receiving as needed (prn) morphine, her breathing status would typically improve. A steroid taper was begun. The patient should continue prednisone 30 mg daily for 3 more days, then 20 mg daily for 4 days, then 10 mg daily for 4 days, then 5 mg daily for 4 days, then stop.

# Upper Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding: On [Date], patient had coffee grounds from Orogastric (OG) tube. Lavage for approximately 600ccs with clearance. Gastrointestinal (GI) performed Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) which revealed esophagitis, ulcers and blood in the stomach body, D2 diverticulum and large hiatal hernia. Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) was negative. Patient was continued on intravenous (IV) Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI), with plan for repeat EGD in 8 weeks, and upper GI series once clinically improved given abnormal anatomy on EGD. Her hematocrit remained stable with no further episodes of upper GI bleeding throughout the patient's hospitalization. On the floor she was switched to oral (PO) pantoprazole twice daily. Aspirin was held.

# Weakness: The patient was found to have generalized weakness at the end of her hospitalization. Neurology was consulted and they felt it was likely due to a combination of steroid myopathy and deconditioning from her prolonged bedbound status. A Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH) was checked which was normal. They recommended pulmonary and physical rehab.

# Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): History of Left Anterior Descending (LAD) and Right Coronary Artery (RCA) stenosis on Cardiac Catheterization (Cath), but no stents. Continued statin and beta blocker, but held aspirin for GI bleeding (see above).

# Nutrition: Unable to pass Nasogastric (NG) tube without direct visualization due to hiatal hernia. Interventional Radiology (IR) guided post pyloric NG tube was placed on [Date] for Tube Feedings (TFs) and PO medications. NG tube was pulled when patient was extubated on [Date]. Speech and swallow were consulted following the patient's extubation and she was eventually moved to soft solids and thin liquids with 1:1 supervision.

# Goals of care: Primary Care Physician (PCP) [Name] was very involved in discussions regarding patient's code status. Palliative care also followed along with the patient. Ultimately, at the time of the patient's extubation on [Date], it was decided that the patient would be Do Not Resuscitate/Do Not Intubate (DNR/DNI) (although this was later changed). The patient's family felt that she would not want a tracheostomy. It was decided that she would not be reintubated and that, if her respiratory status were to worsen after intubation, care would be focused on comfort. However, her status improved in the MICU and on the floor and it was then decided that she would remain DNR with intubation (but no tracheostomy) if her breathing deteriorated. After several days with stable or improved overall clinical status, she was deemed suitable for rehabilitation. At the time of discharge, the patient's code status was do not resuscitate, okay to intubate.
